summary: G. Robert Blakey was involved with the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA). As indicated by a letter dated July 19, 1978, he requested assistance from Scott Breckinridge at the CIA to arrange interviews in Mexico with individuals like June Cobb Sharp and Henry P. Lopez. This suggests Blakey was actively involved in the investigation of the JFK assassination, specifically in gathering information from potential witnesses or persons of interest in Mexico. He also oversaw the payroll for the Select Committee on Assassinations, as evidenced by a certification report from March 7, 1979. The documents indicate his involvement spanned from at least July 1978 to March 1979, focusing on investigative activities and administrative responsibilities within the HSCA.
significance: G. Robert Blakey served as counsel or a leading figure for the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA), playing a key role in directing the investigation into the JFK assassination. His requests for CIA assistance in arranging interviews in Mexico highlight the HSCA's efforts to gather information from various sources and locations relevant to the assassination.
